questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy presents with a year-long history of bilateral nasal congestion without drainage or fevers. His parents note that he snores every night and only breathes through his mouth. He has restless sleep, but they have not witnessed any apneas. He has tried saline spray and nasal fluticasone spray for 2 months and completed a course of amoxicillin-clavulanate, but his symptoms have persisted. His parents feel that he is not getting quality sleep because of the restlessness. His only current medication is the fluticasone spray. He has no known medication or environmental allergies.
On physical examination, he is afebrile with a normal respiratory rate. He has hyponasal speech, no turbinate hypertrophy or rhinorrhea, and no polyps identified in the nasal cavity. His tonsils are 1+ bilaterally. His heart and lung examinations are normal.
A sleep study yields the following results:

Apnea-hypopnea index: 2 events per hour (normal, <5)
Mean oxygen saturation: 98%
Nadir oxygen saturation: 96%
Expired carbon dioxide levels >50%: 0 minutes

What is the best next step in evaluating this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Place a nasal suction catheter in each naris
Supervise the parent in occluding one naris at a time and blowing into the child’s mouth
Begin continuous positive airway pressure at home

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Azelastine nasal spray is indicated for patients with chronic rhinitis, but this patient’s presentation is not consistent with this diagnosis, and azelastine is therefore not the most appropriate intervention. Although this patient has nasal blockage, he lacks the other characteristic symptoms of chronic rhinitis (including postnasal drip, sneezing, and rhinorrhea) and has no turbinate hypertrophy on physical examination. Furthermore, allergic rhinitis usually improves with a trial of nasal glucocorticoid spray, which was not seen here.

B) CORRECT:

The most common cause of nasal congestion in the presence of mouth breathing, snoring, and hyponasal speech is enlarged adenoid tissue. The adenoid tissue obstructs the choana, resulting in the mouth breathing and hyponasal speech. Affected children may snore as a result but rarely have apneic events in the absence of tonsillar enlargement. A normal sleep study does not rule out adenoidal hypertrophy. The most appropriate next step to evaluate this patient’s symptoms is either a soft-tissue lateral nasopharyngeal radiograph or referral to an otolaryngologist for nasopharyngoscopy.

A child who presents with nasal congestion, mouth breathing, and snoring in the absence of documented sleep apnea or tonsillar enlargement most likely has enlarged adenoid tissue.

C) INCORRECT:

Nasogastric tube placement to assess for patency of the nares is commonly employed in the newborn period to assess for choanal atresia. Bilateral choanal atresia, which results in no air flow from the nose, is diagnosed at birth, as neonates are obligate nasal breathers. Unilateral choanal atresia can manifest later with chronic nasal congestion, but drainage from a single side (secondary to mucus buildup) is more typical. Although unilateral choanal atresia could be a potential diagnosis in this case (and would be confirmed with a nasopharyngeal scope or CT of the face), another condition should be ruled out first.

D) INCORRECT:

In the case of a suspected nasal foreign body, parents are sometimes instructed to perform “the parent’s kiss,” where they create a seal around the child’s mouth and blow into it while pressing against the naris that is not affected by the foreign body; the goal is to dislodge the foreign body or move it to a position more amenable for removal. This intervention would be indicated in the presence of a known foreign body or unilateral nasal discharge, especially if it was foul smelling. This patient has no history to suggest a foreign body, and he has bilateral congestion without drainage.

E) INCORRECT:

Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) is commonly used to treat obstructive sleep apnea but is not indicated in this patient, given that his sleep study was normal with an apnea-hypopnea index (AHI) of 2. The AHI is the number of apneic or hypopneic events divided by the number of hours of sleep; a value < 5 is considered normal.
